text: Zac Poonen commentary: The beginning of all things is God creating...
The earth was formless and void, indicating the need for God's work.
The children of Israel in Egypt, setting the stage for deliverance.

This verse, along with verse 2, contains fundamental statements about Jesus Christ, the 'Word'. The Word is a title for Jesus Christ, representing the visible expression of the invisible God, similar to how spoken words express a person's thoughts. The 'Word' existed from the beginning, meaning from all eternity, a time that predates the creation described in Genesis 1:1. The verse also states 'the Word was with God,' which indicates there was another person who was also God, identified as the Father, with whom Christ was. The third statement, 'the Word was God,' makes it clear that Jesus Christ is God Himself. From this verse, it's concluded that God is more than one person, existing in three persons—Father, Son, and Holy Spirit—all of whom are equally and eternally God, yet there is only one God, not three gods.
This verse repeats the idea that Christ was in the beginning with God , emphasizing that Jesus existed with the Father from all eternity.

This verse corresponds to Genesis 1:1 and states that all things came into being through Christ. The heaven, the earth, and everything in it were created through Him, and nothing was created apart from Him. The Hebrew word for 'God' in Genesis 1:1, 'Elohim,' is a plural word, which signifies that God is more than one person, supporting the idea that creation was a work of the triune God.

'In Him was life,' can only be said about God, as only God has life in Himself. All other created beings have life derived from God. Jesus said, 'I am the way, the truth, and the life,' emphasizing that He has life in Himself. This life is not just existence but refers to the very nature of God manifested in Jesus's life. This life was also the 'light of men,' a light that comes from God and is meant for humanity to walk in. The light that Christ brought to earth was not a primary doctrine or a teaching, but a life. When Christianity becomes focused on doctrines or patterns instead of this life, it has 'missed the main thing'. While doctrines and patterns are not unimportant, they are secondary to the life of Christ, which is what makes a person a Christian. Unity comes from the life of Jesus, not from a specific doctrine or church pattern.

'The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not overpower it,' explains that the life of God cannot be overcome by darkness. A Christian who has received the life of Jesus, which is the light of the world, will shine regardless of how dark, evil, or filthy their surroundings are. Sin is stronger than human will, and Satan is stronger than human power. The secret to a victorious life is not in doctrine, determination, or self-discipline, but in receiving the life of God. It is impossible to overcome sin and darkness without receiving the life of God through the Holy Spirit. The light will overpower the darkness when a person yields to the Holy Spirit and allows Him to take possession of their entire being.

This verse introduces John the Baptist as a man 'sent from God'. To effectively preach Christ, a person must be sent by God, as John the Baptist was. If a person undertakes ministry without being sent by God, it will only lead to confusion. The Apostle Paul serves as an example, stating that Christ Jesus put him into the ministry, not a human being. An effective ministry requires a personal, face-to-face relationship with Christ where He has commissioned you. John the Baptist was an ordinary man without a title, which is presented as a good example for those in ministry to follow.

John the Baptist came to bear witness to the 'light,' which is the life of God manifested in Jesus Christ. He did not come to preach theories or to present himself, but to bear witness to the life of Christ. A person can only bear witness to that life if they have partaken of it themselves.

John the Baptist was 'not the light,' but came to bear witness to the light. The ultimate purpose of a witness is to draw people to Christ, not to oneself. John the Baptist's goal was to lead people to faith in Christ and turn their attention away from himself. He is an example for ministers who should not try to present themselves as the light but should lift up Christ so that people are drawn to Him. John said, 'Jesus must increase. I must decrease,' providing a model for true and effective ministry.

Jesus Christ is the 'true light' who came into the world to give light to 'every man'. The world as a whole has benefited from His coming, even though only a few have received salvation. Whether a person responds to that light and allows it to enter their life is a personal choice.

Jesus was in the world, a world that was made through Him, yet the world did not know Him. This is because He came as a very simple person, without the pomp, show, or qualifications that the world typically values, such as wealth, high family, or education. The world did not value the 'life from God,' which was the important thing. The same is true today; men of God are often not appreciated because love, humility, and purity are not valued as they should be. The church's calling is to show the world the life of Jesus, which is seen in humility, purity, and love, not in power or wealth.

Jesus 'came to His own,' referring to the Jewish people who had received the revelation of God since the days of Abraham and Moses. Despite being His own people, they did not receive Him; in fact, they crucified Him. It was the Jewish high priests and religious people, not the Roman soldiers or Pilate, who wanted to kill Jesus. Religious people have historically been the greatest persecutors of the true disciples of Jesus.

'As many as received Him, to them He gave the right to become children of God'. This right is not based on good works or accomplishments but on receiving Christ, the light of all men. Receiving Him means opening one's entire being to the life of God, desiring His life to come in and drive out the darkness of sin and worldliness. It is a personal act of receiving Christ, not just repeating a formula with one's lips. 'To believe in His name' is synonymous with receiving Him; it is not merely intellectual belief, as even demons believe and shudder. To believe in Jesus's name means to believe that He can save you from your sins and to desire that salvation. It is a trust that is likened to a bride committing her whole life to her bridegroom.

Becoming a child of God is a supernatural birth, what Jesus calls being 'born again' or the 'new birth'. This birth is not the result of: 1) **blood relationship.** A person cannot become a child of God simply because their parents were Christians. Each person must personally receive Christ. 2) **the will of the flesh.** This refers to self-will and human determination; no amount of human discipline, asceticism, or self-control can make a person a child of God. 3) **the will of man.** No other person, regardless of their actions like laying on of hands, confirming, or baptizing, can make someone a child of God. This birth must come from God. It is a supernatural work of the Holy Spirit, similar to how the body of Jesus was supernaturally created in Mary's womb. While a person must submit, the birth itself is a work of the Holy Spirit. Without this inward birth, a person is not a child of God.

'The Word became flesh' means that the Word, who was God and existed from all eternity, became like us. 'Flesh' is a term used to describe the human race after the fall of Adam, a state with lusts and desires. Jesus came 'in the likeness of sinful flesh' so that He could be tempted in all points as we are. However, even though He came in our flesh, He never sinned in any way. In His flesh, He manifested the glory of God, which is a perfect balance of grace and truth. Jesus emptied Himself of the 'fullness of God,' meaning the privileges and powers He had as God, while retaining His deity. The mystery of godliness is that God was revealed in the flesh. The message for believers is that through the power of the Holy Spirit, the same glory of God can be manifested in our own flesh as well, as we do not have to yield to its lusts.

In this verse, John the Baptist states 'He who comes after me has a higher rank than I, for he existed before me'. This highlights Jesus's eternal existence. Jesus, who was born to earth after John, existed from all eternity in heaven. While Jesus was the 'only begotten' from the Father, today He is the 'firstborn among many brethren,' as God now has many sons.

From the fullness of Jesus, believers have all received 'grace upon grace'. This means that believers can partake of the same fullness of grace and truth that was in Christ. Paul's prayer for the Ephesians to be 'filled with all the fullness of God' shows that this is possible for believers. This is received through God's free grace.

This verse contrasts the Old Covenant, which was the law given through Moses, with the New Covenant, which brought 'grace and truth' through Jesus Christ. The same grace and truth manifested in Christ can now be manifested in our flesh, which is the 'good news' of the gospel. The difference between an admirer of Jesus and a follower is that an admirer praises Jesus's wonderful life but believes they cannot be like Him, while a follower is called to 'follow me'. Many Christians today say things with their lips but their hearts go after their own lusts, just like the people in the Old Testament. The good news is that the same grace and truth seen in Jesus's flesh can now be seen in us through the Holy Spirit's power.

No one has ever seen God, which is why the Word had to become flesh. If Jesus had come as a spirit, people could not have seen Him, felt His touch, or heard His words. The 'only begotten God' who is in the 'bosom of the Father' has 'explained Him'. Jesus explained God to the world not primarily through words but through His life. Believers, who are now called the body of Christ, have the same calling as Jesus: to explain God to people by manifesting grace and truth in their lives. The church is called the body of Christ because its function is to continue the ministry of Christ, which is to manifest the glory of God to the world.

This is the witness of John when the Jews sent to him priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him who are you. He confessed and did not deny, and he confessed, 'I am not the Christ.' John was very faithful; he never sought to draw attention away from Christ to himself, a mark of a true servant of God who seeks to stay in the background and draw people to Jesus himself. They asked him, 'What then?'
He confessed and did not deny, 'I am not the Christ'.
They asked him, 'Are you Elijah?' and he said, 'I am not.' 'Are you the Prophet?' and he answered, 'No.' He had very low thoughts about himself.
They said, 'Then who are you so that we may give an answer to those who sent us? What do you say about yourself?'

He said, 'I am only a voice.' He didn't want to be known or to have other people recognize his face. It was enough that people heard the voice; there was no need even to see the face. He was a voice of one crying in the wilderness, 'Make straight the way of the Lord,' as Isaiah the prophet said. This is a prophecy from Isaiah chapter 40, and he was only fulfilling that. He was a voice crying in the wilderness saying, 'Give up your crookedness and make the way of the Lord straight,' the very message that the Jewish people of his time needed to hear, for they had corrupted the way of the Lord in the eyes of the people.
These people who came to ask John were sent from the Pharisees.
They asked him, 'Why then are you baptizing if you are not the Messiah, the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the Prophet?'

John answered them, 'I baptize in water, but among you stands one whom you do not know,' referring to Christ. It is he who comes after me, the thong of whose sandal I am not worthy to untie. He recognized that he was unfit even to be a slave to Jesus, which shows the tremendous concept he had of our Savior.
It is he who comes after me, the thong of whose sandal I am not worthy to untie.
These things took place in Bethany beyond the Jordan where John was baptizing.

The next day he saw Jesus coming to him and said, 'Behold, the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.' For more than 1,400 years, the Jewish nation had seen lambs being slain every day in the tabernacle first and then in the temple, and they knew this was referring to one who would finally come to be the sacrifice for their sins. The slaying of the Lamb was only symbolic, and now at last He had come. When John the Baptist said 'Behold, the Lamb of God,' he knew that this was the fulfillment of all that Old Testament symbolism and prophecy. Jesus came to take away the sin of the world.

'This is he on behalf of whom I said, after me comes a man who has a higher rank than I, for he existed before me.' John the Baptist says this is the one I was talking about, always the one who existed before me, 'here is he'.
I did not recognize him, but in order that he might be manifested to Israel, I came baptizing in water.
John bore witness saying, 'I have beheld the Spirit descending as a dove out of heaven and he remained upon him.'

'I did not recognize him,' he says again, 'but he who sent me to baptize in water, that is God, said to me, 'He upon whom you see the Spirit descending and remaining upon him, this is the one who baptizes in the Holy Spirit'.' John the Baptist said that he had a very definite word from God that when you see the Spirit descending upon one and remaining upon him, that is the one who will baptize other people in the Holy Spirit. John the Baptist says, 'I am only baptizing in water, but this one who is greater than me is going to baptize in the Holy Spirit'. The word baptism is a Greek word which means immersion. Jesus is called here the immerser in the Holy Spirit, like John was an immerser. John the Baptist means John the immerser, the one who was plunging people into the water. In the same way, Jesus is also a plunger or an immerser in the Holy Spirit. He drenches us with the Holy Spirit's power. This was never possible under the Old Testament, but here in the New Testament, Jesus baptizes or immerses in the Holy Spirit. This promise is repeated in the first five books of the Bible in Matthew chapter 3, Mark chapter 1, Luke chapter 3, John chapter 1, and Acts chapter 1. We read of the baptism in the Holy Spirit or of being baptized in the Holy Spirit or of being immersed in the Holy Spirit. The very first two promises in the New Testament are: the first in Matthew 1:21, 'You shall call his name Jesus for he shall save his people from their sins,' and the second in Matthew chapter 3 is, 'He shall baptize you in the Holy Spirit' (Matthew 3:11). These are the two experiences that we need to know as children of God: first, being saved from our sins; second, being baptized or immersed in the Holy Spirit and fire. The Holy Spirit is symbolized as fire that burns up the chaff and comes and endues us with power. It's like the petrol being ignited in a scooter or a car with fire so that it propels the vehicle forward. Without the fire, any amount of petrol in the vehicle is no use; it needs the spark, the fire, to propel it. What many believers need today is the fire of the Holy Spirit. Their tanks are full of petrol, full of the word of God, but the power, the fire, is missing, and so they are pushing their vehicles instead of driving them. What you need is to be baptized in the Holy Spirit, to be immersed in the Holy Spirit and fire. There is only one whom God has appointed to baptize in the Holy Spirit, and that is Jesus himself. A man can baptize you in water, but only Jesus can baptize you in the Holy Spirit. Here is a promise: Jesus is the one who baptizes or immerses in the Holy Spirit. This is not a point to be discussed and argued theologically; it is something to be experienced in our life. It is impossible to live the Christian life without this power.

The third thing John says here is concerning Christ, 'I have seen and have borne witness that this is the Son of God.' There are three things here in verses 29 to 34. First, the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world. We need to experience him like that, the Lamb of God who has taken away my sin. Secondly, verse 33, this is the one who baptizes in the Holy Spirit. I need to know him as the one who has immersed me, who immerses me in the Holy Spirit. And third, 'this is the Son of God'. I need to worship him as the one who is the Son of God from all eternity, my Lord and my Savior. Don't miss out on any of these.
And again, the next day John was standing and two of his disciples, and he looked upon Jesus and he said, 'Behold, the Lamb of God,' or 'look, there is the Lamb of God'.
He looked upon Jesus and said, 'Behold, the Lamb of God.'

Two of his disciples heard him speak and they followed Jesus. What a wonderful testimony if it can be said of us who preach the word that they heard him speak and they followed Jesus. If it can be said about you, 'they heard you speak and they didn't follow you, they followed Jesus,' that is a true servant of God. They heard him speak and they didn't follow him; they followed Jesus. Beautiful words.

Jesus turned and beheld them following and said to them, 'What do you seek?' That is a question he always asks those who turn around, those who come to him: what are you seeking? Are you seeking money, health, honor, position, a job, or are you seeking salvation, power, being saved from sin (verse 29), the baptism in the Holy Spirit? What are you seeking? That is a question he asks us even today. And they said, 'Where are you staying? We'd like to be with you.' What a wonderful desire to be with you.

Jesus said to them, 'Come and you will see.' They came therefore and saw where he was staying and stayed with him that day, for it was about the tenth hour. Even today Jesus says to the world, 'Come and see.' Where is he dwelling today? He is dwelling in the church, in the midst of the church (Revelation 1). He tells the world today, 'Come and see how I am living in the midst of the church.' This is our calling, brothers and sisters, who are listening: our calling is to represent Christ in such a way that we can invite the world into our churches, into our homes, and say, 'Come and see how Jesus dwells in our midst'.
One of the two who heard John speak and followed Jesus was Andrew, Simon Peter's brother.

He found first his own brother Simon and said to him, 'We have found the Messiah,' which translated means Christ. What a wonderful man John the Baptist was that he just let two of his disciples go and follow Jesus. That was his calling, and that's our calling too, dear friends who preach the word: to draw people to Jesus so that they follow him and that they don't have any connection with us as if we were their head, but that they are connected to the Lord and follow him. Andrew found his own brother Simon, and there again we can learn something. We have a responsibility to bring others in our own family to Christ if Christ has laid hold of us. Have you found Jesus as your savior? Find your brother, tell him about Jesus, tell your relatives about Jesus. This is evangelism; personal evangelism begins in our family. Why has God laid hold of one person in a family? The purpose is to reach other members in that family. He found first his own brother Simon, a message that you and I need to take heed to. Have we found our own brother, sister?

He said to him, 'We have found Christ.' And he brought Simon to Jesus. Jesus looked at him and said, 'You are Simon the son of John; you shall be called Cephas,' which translated means Peter or a small rock or stone, not a big rock like the one Jesus spoke about in Matthew 16:18, 'Petra,' that rock is Christ himself. But this is a small stone, 'Petros.' 'You are a small stone that will be built on the big rock as a part of the church'.
The next day Jesus purposed to go forth into Galilee and he found Philip, and Jesus said to him, 'Follow me.' just two words: 'follow me'.
Philip was from Bethsaida, the same city as Andrew and Peter.

What did Philip do? He engaged in personal evangelism too. He found Nathanael and said to him, 'We have found him of whom Moses in the law and also the prophets wrote: Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.' As soon as people found the Messiah, they told others, and that's what we need to do too.

Nathanael said to him, 'Can any good thing come out of Nazareth?' and Philip said to him, 'Come and see.' Always that message: 'Come and see.' Jesus said, 'Come and see' (verse 39), and that is the message we need to proclaim in the church today. 'Come and see' what the Lord has done in our midst. 'Come and see' how we live together as husband and wife. 'Come and see' how we live together in fellowship in the church. Unfortunately, the message that many Christian churches are preaching today is only 'come and hear,' 'come and hear' this new doctrine that we have, 'come and hear' this new preacher who has come from some other country. No, that's not primarily what we are to say, but 'come and see' what this message has produced. If it has not produced anything, then what is the use of telling them to come and hear? What has it produced in your relationship with your wife or your husband, or in you as a father towards your children? Has it made you more patient? Has it made you overcome anger in your home? Have you stopped shouting at your wife? Can you say to others, 'Come and see what the gospel has produced in my home'? Otherwise, we should hang our head in shame and repent and seek God and say, 'Lord, help me to so live such a life that I can invite others to come and see.' And not only that, what about your thought life, your heart, your thoughts? Can you invite people to come inside your thoughts? If it were possible to see the purity and peace that there is in your thoughts. 'Come and see' is the message that we need to proclaim; otherwise, we shall be empty talkers. Paul speaks in Titus chapter 1 about empty talkers. We must never become empty talkers.

Jesus saw Nathanael coming to him from a distance and said of him, 'Behold, an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile.' What a wonderful commendation if Jesus can say that about you and me: 'an Israelite in whom there is no guile,' no hypocrisy. Not perfect, not sinless, but no pretense. That is what we need to hear. First of all, Nathanael was not even converted; he was not born again. He hadn't come to a life of victory over sin, but he was free from pretense and hypocrisy and guile, and that is the first step. Jesus chooses such people, Jesus calls such people even today. What is he looking for? Freedom from hypocrisy and pretense and guile. Does he find that in you, dear friend? Does he find freedom from hypocrisy and guile and pretense in you as he did in Nathanael? Then there is great hope.

Nathanael said to him, 'How do you know me?' and Jesus answered and said to him, 'Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you.' What do you think Nathanael was doing under the fig tree? Quietly alone in some place under a fig tree, he was kneeling down and praying to God. Jesus said, 'I saw you there.' By supernatural revelation, Jesus had seen what Nathanael had done.

Nathanael answered and said, 'Rabbi, you are the Son of God; you are the King of Israel.' Nathanael knew that no one had seen him there under the fig tree except God, and when Jesus supernaturally spoke that word, immediately his heart was open.

Jesus answered and said, 'Do you believe because I said to you that I saw you under the fig tree? Is it because of something supernatural like this that you believe? You will see greater things than these'.

What will you see? He said to him, 'Truly I say to you, you shall see the heavens opened and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of Man.' This is a reference to the time when Jacob lay down in Bethel and had a dream and he saw a ladder going up to heaven and the angels of God ascending and descending on that ladder. Here Jesus says that that ladder is the Son of Man. That ladder was a picture of Christ all the way from heaven down to the earth with its last rung right down, with its feet of the ladder right placed on earth. The Word became flesh; he became exactly like us, he was made like his brethren (Hebrews 2:17) in all things. He is the only ladder to heaven; he is the only way that we can go up into God's kingdom. It's very significant that he refers to that incident in Jacob's life here, because Jacob was the one whose name was changed to Israel, and in Jacob at that time there was a lot of guile and deception. He had deceived his father before running away saying that he was Esau. But now in Nathanael, we read a person in whom we can read John 1:47 like this, 'Behold an Israelite indeed in whom there is no Jacob,' in whom there is no guile. And that is our calling today: there should be no Jacob in us, no deceiving of others, no pretense, no pretending to be Esau, but a true Israelite freed from hypocrisy. Such a person sees Jesus as the ladder from earth to heaven and the angels of God ascending and descending upon him.

On the third day there was a wedding in Cana of Galilee and the mother of Jesus was there. Jesus was also invited and his disciples to the wedding. Jesus went to wedding receptions. There was nothing wrong in that. Jesus enjoyed going to such functions; he was not an ascetic like John the Baptist. He had come to establish a new covenant.
Jesus was also invited and his disciples to the wedding.
At that wedding the wine gave out and the mother of Jesus said to him, 'They have no wine.' Mary thought the old relationship was still valid where he had obeyed her for thirty years.

Jesus said to her, 'Woman, what do I have to do with you? My hour has not yet come.' Jesus made it very clear to Mary right at the outset of his ministry that he had no relationship with her now like he had for 30 years in Nazareth as her obedient son. We read in Luke 2:52 that Jesus went down to Nazareth and he was subject to Joseph and Mary all through those years. He continued in subjection to them. But now a time had come after his baptism where he entered into his ministry as the Messiah and it was very important for Mary to recognize that that old relationship was gone. So he turns around to her and says words which are very strong. He calls her 'woman,' not mother, but 'woman.' He had never spoken to her like this in all his 30 years in Nazareth; there he had called her mother. But now he entered into his ministry as the savior of the world and he did not want any human attachment anymore to his relatives. The blood relationship meant nothing. Later on he once said, 'Who are my mother and my brothers and my sisters? These who hear the word of God and do it, these who do the will of God.' So Jesus broke off that human relationship to his relatives and that is what he told his disciples too: 'If you want to be my disciples you got to hate your father, mother, brother, sister, wife and children,' which means 'break off that human relationship.' Jesus sets an example. 'What do I have to do with you?' that old relationship is no longer valid. 'My hour has not yet come.' Now I respond to the leading of the Holy Spirit. It's very important for us to recognize that in Christ the earthly relationships are broken. We come into a new creation and new relationships with brothers and sisters in the church. The expression 'my hour has not yet come' means that he would do things only when prompted and led by the Holy Spirit. He was not going to respond to human ideas and suggestions of what they felt was necessary, but to the leading of the Holy Spirit.
So his mother recognized that a new relationship had now come, so she just said to the servants, 'Whatever he says to you, do it.' Beautiful words that we can listen to: 'whatever he says'.
Now there were six stone water pots set there for the Jewish custom of purification, containing twenty or thirty gallons each.
Jesus said to them, 'Fill the water pots with water,' and they filled them up to the brim.
He said to them, 'Draw some out now and take it to the head waiter,' and they took it to him.

When the head waiter tasted the water which had become wine, he said, 'You have kept the good wine until now.' The beginning of his signs Jesus did in Cana of Galilee and manifested his glory, and his disciples believed in him. There are a number of things that we can learn from this miracle. One is that where Jesus is not given the first place, the wine will always run out. In every marriage, the wine of joy and abundance will run out if Jesus is not present. But if he is there, he will always make sure there is an abundance. He can take the water, the ordinary things of life, and turn it into wine from heaven, supernaturally bringing something glorious into a very ordinary thing. He does not do it all by himself; he seeks to work together with us. Right through John's gospel we see the principle of the new covenant, which is partnership with Jesus. We don't do it alone; neither does Jesus do it alone. It is in fellowship with us that he works. He could have created water in those water pots without a problem, but he doesn't do it. He asks the servants to fill the water pots with water and then he turns the water into wine. So the servants also had a part in it because they filled the water pots with water and they drew it out and served it. It was a cooperation, a partnership that Jesus was trying to teach his disciples and all of us. The Christian life is a partnership where we take his yoke upon us and work together with him. There were six stone water pots set there for the Jewish custom of purification, containing twenty or thirty gallons each. Jesus said to them, 'Fill the water pots with water.' That's the other thing we learn here: that we have to work hard, no half-heartedness, fill it up to the brim, up to the brim, with complete wholeheartedness, hard work. And then Jesus does a miracle. He doesn't do what we can do; he does what we cannot do.
He said, 'You have kept the good wine until now.'
The beginning of his signs Jesus did in Cana of Galilee and manifested his glory and his disciples believed in him.
After this he went down to Capernaum, he and his mother and his brothers and his disciples and there they stayed a few days.

And the Passover of the Jews was at hand and Jesus went up to Jerusalem. This was the first Passover that Jesus went to, which is recorded in the gospel of John. At that time, in Jerusalem, the Jews were carrying out certain customs which God had never commanded them to do. They were very religious, but they were doing things that were not commanded by God. Jesus had to cleanse the temple.

He found in the temple those who were selling oxen and sheep and doves and the money changers sitting down. Why was he so angry? The temple was called by the Lord's house, a house of prayer for all nations. But they had turned it into a house of merchandise. This is what Jesus was angry about. The house of God has to be a house of prayer, a house of fellowship, a house for people to be quiet and get in touch with God. It is not meant to be a house of merchandise where people are selling things.

He made a scourge of cords and drove them all out of the temple with the sheep and the oxen and he poured out the coins of the money changers and overturned their tables. The one who was full of grace and truth manifested his glory. When we think of Jesus, we must not think of him as a milk and water person. He was a person full of zeal for God's house.
And to those who were selling the doves he said, 'Take these things away. Stop making my father's house a house of merchandise.'
His disciples remembered that it was written, 'Zeal for thy house will consume me.' When Jesus cleansed the temple, he was manifesting his divine glory. His zeal for his Father's house was so great.

The Jews therefore said to him, 'What sign do you show to us since you do these things?' They were not concerned with his zeal for God's house, but they wanted to see a sign, a miracle, a sensational thing. They wanted to test him. The same is true of religious people today.
Jesus answered and said to them, 'Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up.' He was referring to the temple of his body, but they did not understand.
The Jews therefore said, 'It took forty-six years to build this temple and will you raise it up in three days?'
But he was speaking of the temple of his body.
When therefore he was raised from the dead, his disciples remembered that he said this and they believed the scripture and the word which Jesus had spoken.

Now when he was in Jerusalem at the Passover, during the feast, many believed in his name, beholding his signs which he was doing. They believed on the basis of seeing miracles. But Jesus had no faith in their faith.

But Jesus on his part was not entrusting himself to them, for he knew all men. He knew that their faith was based on sensationalism. He was not entrusting himself to them because he knew that their faith was not rooted in a changed heart.
And because he did not need anyone to bear witness concerning man, for he himself knew what was in man. He knew what was in their hearts.
Now there was a man of the Pharisees named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews.
